([[Chairman]] & [[Chief executive officer|CEO]]) | industry = [[Aerospace engineering|Aerospace]] and [[Military|Defense]] | products = Investment castings, forged products, fasteners | revenue = {{increase}} [[United States dollar|US$]]9.6 billion (FY 2014){{cite web|url=http://pdf.secdatabase.com/1401/0000079958-12-000015.pdf |title=Precision Castparts 2012 Annual Report, Form 10-K, Filing Date May 31, 2012 |publisher=secdatabase.com |accessdate =June 8, 2012}} | operating_income = {{increase}} US$2.6 billion (FY 2014) | net_income = {{increase}} US$1.7 billion (FY 2014) | assets = {{increase}} US$18.5 billion (FY 2014) | equity = {{increase}} US$11.4 billion (FY 2014) | num_employees = 30,100 (March 2015) | parent = [[Berkshire Hathaway]] | divisions = PCC Airfoils, PCC Structurals, PCC Energy Group, PCC Fasteners, PCC Aerostructures | subsid = [[Wyman-Gordon]], [[Special Metals Corporation]], [[Titanium Metals Corporation]], Texas Honing Inc. | homepage = {{URL|http://www.precast.com}} }} '''Precision Castparts Corp.''' is an American industrial goods and [[fabrication (metal)|metal fabrication]] company that manufactures investment castings, forged components, and airfoil castings for use in the [[aerospace]], industrial gas turbine, and defense industries. In 2009 it ranked 362nd on the [[Fortune 500]] list, and 11th in the aerospace and defense industry.[http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune500/2009/snapshots/955.html Precision Castparts.] Fortune 500: 2009. CNNMoney.com. Retrieved on April 20, 2009. In 2015 it ranked 322nd overall and 9th in the aerospace and defense industry.{{cite web|url=http://fortune.com/fortune500/precision-castparts-corp-322/|title=Fortune 500|author=Brett Krasnove|date=June 3, 2015|work=Fortune|access-date=April 16, 2016}} In 2014 it ranked 133rd on the S&P 500 based on market capitalization.{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/dividendchannel/2014/09/08/precision-castparts-takes-over-133-spot-from-kraft-foods-group/|title=Precision Castparts Takes Over #133 Spot From Kraft Foods Group|author=Dividend Channel|date=September 8, 2014|work=Forbes}} In January 2016, the company became a [[subsidiary]] of [[Berkshire Hathaway]].{{cite news|last=Rogoway|first=Mike|title=Precision Castparts' $37B sale finalized|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/business/index.ssf/2016/01/precision_castparts_sale_is_fi.html|accessdate=2016-02-02|newspaper=The Oregonian|date=January 30, 2016|page=C8|orig-year=first published online January 29}} Before that event, it used to be one of the three Fortune 500 companies headquartered in [[Oregon]]. ==History== Precision Castparts (PCC) was founded by [[Joseph Buford Cox]] on April 1, 1953.[http://www.precast.com/PCC/History_txt.html History.] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20020311141228/http://www.precast.com/PCC/History_txt.html |date=March 11, 2002 }} Precision Castparts. Retrieved on February 28, 2008. Cox was owner of Oregon Saw Chain and in 1949 had started a casting operation with assistant general manager Ed Cooley also working on the project. In 1953 Cox separated the two companies and PCC was formed, moving into a new larger facility in 1955, and incorporating the following year with Ed Cooley as one of the owners. ===1960s and 1970s=== Beginning in the 1960s, the company began to secure contracts to provide parts for jet engines. In 1967 they were awarded a contract by [[General Electric]] to provide parts for their TF39 engine and another contract with [[Pratt & Whitney]]. The following year the company was taken public and began work with [[Boeing]]. In 1968 Precision Castparts became a public company with the offering 120,000 shares of common stock to 1,100 new shareholders.{{cite web|url=http://www.precast.com/overview/history/|title=Welcome to Precision Castparts Corp.|work=Precision Castparts Corp.}} By the 1970s PCC was also casting parts for body part replacements such as hips and knees. ===1980s and 1990s=== In the early 1980s, PCC expanded their facilities with several additions. In 1985 the company acquired a titanium foundry in Europe and built a new plant the next year in France. Over the next few years PCC acquired other companies such as Airfoils, and AETC Limited of [[United Kingdom|Britain]]. In 1989, PCC was listed on the New York Stock Exchange, trading as PCP. In 1991, Bill McCormick became CEO. Acquisitions continued in the 1990s with Advanced Forming Technology, ACC Electronics, Quamco, Astro Punch, and Olofsson Corporation. In 1997 PCC bought J&L Fiber Services, Pittler Maschinenfabrik GmbH, and Schlosser Casting Company. Over the next ten years the company continued to grow through acquiring other companies around the world in places such as [[Romania]], Scotland, Switzerland, and Australia as well as companies within the United States including SPS Technologies.Giegerich, Andy. [http://www.bizjournals.com/portland/stories/1999/11/22/story5.html FTC orders Precision to sell Albany metals plant.] ''[[Portland Business Journal]]'', November 19, 1999. One of the company's largest purchases was the $990 million acquisition of [[Wyman-Gordon Company]] in 1999. They have also built or joined with partners to build plants in many countries around the world, including [[India]], the [[Czech Republic]], Hungary, China, and [[Malaysia]]. ===2000s to present=== In 2002, Mark Donegan became President and CEO. Precision received tax breaks from local governments in the Portland metro area in 2006 in exchange for a plant expansion.[[Peter Zuckerman|Zuckerman, Peter]]. Precision's growth will bring 400 new jobs. ''[[The Oregonian]]'', September 25, 2006. In 2007, the company purchased Cherry Aerospace to expand their fastener business.Hunsberger, Brent. Precision Castparts buys maker of fasteners. ''[[The Oregonian]]'', January 9, 2007. After ranking as the 568th largest U.S. company by ''Fortune'' in 2007,{{cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune500/2007/full_list/501_600.html|title=Fortune 500 2007|date=April 30, 2007|publisher=CNNMoney.com|accessdate=2009-07-20}} the company became a [[Fortune 500]] the next year when it ranked 444, and rose to 362 in 2009. It is now ranked at 322. PCC announced the purchase of Carlton Forge Works in October 2009 for $850 million and Primus International Inc. in July 2011 in a $900 million deal. Primus made parts for airplanes, selling their products to both [[Airbus]] and [[Boeing]].{{cite news|title=Portland-based Precision Castparts announces $900 million deal to buy Primus International |date= July 10, 2011|newspaper=[[The Oregonian]] |last=Read|first=Richard}} In May 2012 PCC acquired Centra Industries Inc. a builder of aircraft parts for [[Boeing]], [[Lockheed Martin]], [[Northrop Grumman]], [[Spirit AeroSystems]], [[Mitsubishi Heavy Industries]] and [[Bombardier Inc.|Bombardier]]. They have two plants based in [[Cambridge, Ontario]], [[Canada]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/article/2012-05-07/a3VC8_OrwoRs.html |title=Centra Industries Announces Sale to Precision Castparts Corp. |publisher=Bloomberg |date=2012-05-07 |accessdate=2013-11-21}} Texas Honing was purchased by PCC in October 2012,{{cite news|last=Siemers|first=Erik|title=Precision Castparts acquires Texas Honing|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/portland/morning_call/2012/10/precision-castparts-acquires-texas.html|accessdate=October 8, 2012|newspaper=Portland Business Journal|date=October 8, 2012}} followed by the $2.9 billion acquisition of [[Titanium Metals]] in November 2012.{{cite news|last=Read|first=Richard|title=Precision Castparts to acquire Titanium Metals in $2.9 billion deal|newspaper=[[The Oregonian]]|date=November 9, 2012}} On August 10, 2015, the boards of directors of [[Berkshire Hathaway]] Inc. and Precision Castparts Corp. unanimously approved a definitive agreement for Berkshire Hathaway to acquire, for $235 per share in cash, all outstanding PCC shares, for a total sum of $37 billion including assumed debt.{{Cite web|title = Welcome to Precision Castparts Corp.|url = http://www.precast.com/investors/press_release/?id=666|website = www.precast.com|accessdate = 2015-08-10}} The sale was finalized on January 29, 2016, on which date Berkshire Hathaway took ownership of Precision Castparts. ==Environment== In May 2011, toxic chemicals such as [[nitrogen dioxide]] and [[hydrochloric acid]] were unexpectedly released at the company's titanium plant on Johnson Creek Blvd.{{cite news | url=http://portlandtribune.com/sl/301085-178141-long-history-of-johnson-creek-pollution-winds-back-to-precision-castparts | title=Oregon Local News - Long history of Johnson Creek pollution winds back to Precision Castparts | newspaper=Portland Tribune | author=Paul Koberstein | location=Portland, Oregon | date=April 7, 2016 | access-date=April 16, 2016}} Although four people were hospitalized, nobody was permanently injured from the fumes. Firefighters had difficulty shutting down the plant.{{cite news|title=After a night of tension, confusion and a toxic cloud, Precision Castparts in Oregon says it will make changes to prevent a repeat|newspaper=The Oregonian|date=August 6, 2011|author=Learn, Scott|author2=Feulner, Natalie|location=Portland, Oregon}} The Toxic 100 Air polluters index from the [[University of Massachusetts]] lists Precision Castparts as the number one air polluter in the U.S. in the August 2013 edition,{{cite news|last=Read|first=Richard|title=Portland's Precision Castparts ranked nation's top industrial air polluter in University of Massachusetts study|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/business/index.ssf/2013/08/portlands_precision_castparts_2.html|accessdate=9 November 2013|newspaper=The Oregonian|date=August 26, 2013}} which the company called a flawed study.{{cite news|author=News Staff|title=Precision Castparts: Pollution study ‘deeply flawed'|url=http://www.koin.com/news/multnomah-county/precision-castparts-pollution-study-deeply-flawed|accessdate=9 November 2013|publisher=KOIN 6|date=August 29, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131109221837/http://www.koin.com/news/multnomah-county/precision-castparts-pollution-study-deeply-flawed|archive-date=November 9, 2013|url-status=dead|df=mdy-all}} ==Financials== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Total debt increased by 29 percent, from $677 million in 2006 to $873 million in 2007. The increases in revenue and debt were due in part to a pair of acquisitions in February 2007: GSC Foundries, Inc. (GSC), formerly a competitor to PCP in producing aluminum and steel structural investment castings, and Cherry Aerospace LLC (Cherry), a manufacturer of aerospace blind rivets and blind bolts.[[Wikinvest:Precision Castparts|PCP 2007 10-K, p. 24 via Wikinvest]] ==Products== The company manufactures a variety of parts for the [[aerospace]] industry including many [[jet engine]] components. PCC also makes medical [[prostheses]] and parts for other industrial applications such as in the oil industry, in the gas industry, and for use in power generating turbines for producing electricity. They are considered a leader in the manufacturing of both jet engine airfoils and gas turbines used for generating electricity.Strom, Shelly. [http://www.bizjournals.com/portland/stories/2001/07/16/daily34.html Precision Castparts: Energy markets drive sales.] ''[[Portland Business Journal]]'', July 19, 2001. The company generates $1.5 million in revenue for each Boeing 787 Dreamliner built.Read, Richard. "Boeing's newest bird takes a giant leap forward". ''[[The Oregonian]]'', March 18, 2007. Other products made from the various metals are fasteners, products for the paper industry, parts used in the defense industry, and parts for the automotive industry. PCC's main markets are the United States, [[Europe]], and [[Asia]]. ===Investment cast=== {{Unreferenced section|date=April 2016}}The [[investment casting]] segment of Precision Castparts includes [[PCC Structurals]] and PCC Airfoils. It manufactures castings for [[aircraft engines]], industrial [[gas turbine]] engines, airframes, medical implants, armament, [[unmanned aerial vehicles]], and other industrial applications. They are the market leader in manufacturing large, complex, structural investment castings and the leading manufacturer of airfoil investment castings used in [[jet engines]]. The structural casting business manufactures the largest-diameter, nickel-based super-alloy, titanium and stainless steel investment castings in the world. ===Forged=== The Forged Products segment includes [[Wyman-Gordon]], PCC Energy Group, [[Titanium Metals Corporation]](Timet), and [[Special Metals Corporation]] and serves the aerospace and power generation markets. They produce engine components as well as airframe structural components for both military and commercial aircraft. They also produce mechanical and structural tubular products for use in energy markets.http://www.precast.com/web/user_content/files/743553_002_precision_castparts_corp_bmk1.pdf ===Airframe=== The Airframe Products segment includes PCC Fasteners and PCC Aerostructures. It is the leading developer and manufacturer of highly engineered fasteners, fastener systems, aerostructures and precision components primary used in critical aerospace applications.
